awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). The study of systems of polynomial equations has been a central theme in mathematics for thousands of years, and today related techniques have found applications in fields ranging from cryptography and computer science to mathematical biology. One approach to understanding the solution set of such a system of equations—which dates back to the Greek mathematician Diophantus—is to try to find only those solutions with coordinates in the integers or rational numbers. In cases where our polynomial equations define an algebraic curve, these rational solutions often sit inside a larger, finite set called the set of isolated points of the curve. These can be thought of as “unexpected” solutions to the system of equations, and the ultimate goal of this proposal is to develop new tools for identifying when these solutions occur. Several components of the investigation are suitable for graduate students and other early-career researchers, and their involvement constitutes one of the educational impacts of the proposed work. A second educational endeavor is a research training program involving both incoming Master’s degree students and early undergraduates. At all levels, this program will actively recruit students belonging to groups traditionally underrepresented in the sciences.
 
The central aim of this proposal is to characterize isolated points on modular curves of genus at least 2, motivated by ties to several well-known classification problems and open conjectures. For a fixed family of modular curves, the work proposed falls into two main categories: (1) find all isolated points of any degree corresponding to a certain class of elliptic curves or (2) find all isolated points of a fixed degree corresponding to any elliptic curve. The project pursues several new explanations for isolated points, either by exploiting algebraic structures associated to the curve’s Jacobian or via Arakelov intersection theory. A specific aim is to apply these results to explain certain unexpected isogenies of elliptic curves over quadratic fields. In a different direction, the PI will study classes of isolated points associated to Q-curves motivated by ties to Serre’s Uniformity Conjecture for Galois representations attached to elliptic curves.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This is a project in arithmetic geometry, which is a field in the intersection of algebraic geometry and number theory. Research in this area seeks to uncover interesting properties of geometric objects which transcend the space itself and can be characterized using tools from algebra. Of particular interest for this proposal are "isolated points" on curves, which can be thought of as unexpected solutions to systems of polynomial equations. Some of the most intriguing examples of isolated points lie on modular curves, which are spaces that provide a geometric framework for studying families of elliptic curves. Here, our lack of understanding of isolated points is the central obstruction to open uniformity questions, some of which are more than 50 years old.  

Work supported by this grant developed new methods for ruling out the existence of isolated points on modular curves and explored novel constructions for producing such points. In particular, the project outcomes include:

  • The discovery that there are at most five rational elliptic curves which give rise to isolated points of odd degree on any modular curve X_1(N), giving the first unconditional progress towards a recent finiteness conjecture.
  • The refinement of a technique for producing low-degree points on modular curves by constructing strategic quotients of rational elliptic curves.
  • A new characterization of torsion subgroups arising on CM elliptic curves which ties the problem to determining the infinitude of Sophie Germain primes.

Work related to the project has been widely disseminated in talks given both in and outside of the United States, including plenary talks at conferences in Canada, Croatia, England, France, and Germany. Preprints for all papers are publicly available on arXiv. Much of the research supported by this grant involved junior researchers under the PI's supervision, including work with 5 students and a postdoctoral associate. Several had the opportunity to present their research at national meetings and regional conferences. 

In addition, the grant supported a Research Training Program at the PI's home institution. Through this, incoming math master's degree students received training to develop and lead introductory research projects for early undergraduates. This leadership experience was designed to build graduate students' confidence in their own mathematical potential while providing undergraduates with a unique opportunity for mentored research during the academic year. In spring 2024, a group of 20 undergraduates participated in 8 student-led research projects. Each project culminated with a final presentation and written report.
